citations.narrative:
A single squirrel monkey is housed in a wire frame enclosure that is rusted in many areas of the enclosure including the
wire frame for the food holders. These areas of rust prevent the surfaces from being cleaned and sanitized in accordance
with 3.84(b)(3) and cannot be replaced due to the structural design of the enclosure. This monkey needs to be moved to
an appropriate enclosure that can be cleaned and sanitized effectively for its health and well being.
Correct by: July 18, 2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
A single squirrel monkey was pulled due to conflict in the group. He was placed in an enclosure away from the group and
he has no access to visually see or hear any other species of non-human primates. The facility’s current documented
enrichment plan states, that if an animal is moved for medical purposes, an attempt will be made to house near other non-
human primates, and the animal will have rotated enrichment and their behavior will be evaluated daily. This animal is
displaying abnormal behaviors such as head circling which according to staff was not in his behavior repertoire when
initially moved. The enrichment plan states, “that keepers will be trained to watch for these abnormal behaviors, provide
additional room and increase enrichment”. These strategies documented in the plan are not being followed. The animal
was separated and moved into another building, when he should have been housed close to the group for visual access.
By not following the enrichment plan, the animal is experiencing additional levels of stress leading to the development of
abnormal behaviors and may make it more difficult to reintroduce him into a group of animals.
Correct by: July 17, 2023

Several holding areas including the back holding for tiger and cheetah have metal bars that are rusted with rust actively
flaking off when lightly touched. This amount of rust development does not allow the enclosures to be properly cleaned
and this degree of rust will begin to breakdown the structural integrity of the enclosures. These areas must be addressed
and maintained in good repair to keep the enclosures sound for the safety of the animals.
Correct by: Sept 17, 2023

Two young giraffes are housed in a barn off property that does not have power. There is no outdoor access, and the
windows and doors were not open to allow for fresh air. This barn is not adequately ventilated to provide for the health of
the animals and does not allow the animals access to fresh air. This needs to be addressed for their health and well
being.
Correct by: July 17, 2023

In the drive through portion of the park, there is no shelter for inclement weather provided in the pasture containing the
zebra, wildebeest, guanaco and oryx. A shelter must be provided to afford protection from the elements for the animals
that would choose to use it in order to minimize their discomfort during inclement weather.
Correct by: Aug 30 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the park owner.
n

narrative:
3.80(a)(2)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
A single squirrel monkey is housed in a wire frame enclosure that is rusted in many areas of the enclosure including the 
wire frame for the food holders. These areas of rust prevent the surfaces from being cleaned and sanitized in accordance 
with 3.84(b)(3) and cannot be replaced due to the structural design of the enclosure. This monkey needs to be moved to 
an appropriate enclosure that can be cleaned and sanitized effectively for its health and well being. 
Correct by: July 18, 2023 
3.81(c)(4) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
A single squirrel monkey was pulled due to conflict in the group. He was placed in an enclosure away from the group and 
he has no access to visually see or hear any other species of non-human primates. The facility’s current documented 
enrichment plan states, that if an animal is moved for medical purposes, an attempt will be made to house near other non-
human primates, and the animal will have rotated enrichment and their behavior will be evaluated daily. This animal is 
displaying abnormal behaviors such as head circling which according to staff was not in his behavior repertoire when 
initially moved. The enrichment plan states, “that keepers will be trained to watch for these abnormal behaviors, provide 
additional room and increase enrichment”. These strategies documented in the plan are not being followed. The animal 
was separated and moved into another building, when he should have been housed close to the group for visual access. 
By not following the enrichment plan, the animal is experiencing additional levels of stress leading to the development of 
abnormal behaviors and may make it more difficult to reintroduce him into a group of animals.  
Correct by: July 17, 2023 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Several holding areas including the back holding for tiger and cheetah have metal bars that are rusted with rust actively 
flaking off when lightly touched. This amount of rust development does not allow the enclosures to be properly cleaned 
and this degree of rust will begin to breakdown the structural integrity of the enclosures. These areas must be addressed 
and maintained in good repair to keep the enclosures sound for the safety of the animals.  
Correct by: Sept 17, 2023 
3.126(b)

Facilities, indoor. 
Two young giraffes are housed in a barn off property that does not have power. There is no outdoor access, and the 
windows and doors were not open to allow for fresh air. This barn is not adequately ventilated to provide for the health of 
the animals and does not allow the animals access to fresh air. This needs to be addressed for their health and well 
being.  
Correct by: July 17, 2023 
3.127(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
In the drive through portion of the park, there is no shelter for inclement weather provided in the pasture containing the 
zebra, wildebeest, guanaco and oryx. A shelter must be provided to afford protection from the elements for the animals 
that would choose to use it in order to minimize their discomfort during inclement weather.  
Correct by: Aug 30 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the park owner.
